items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are stable on the River Windrush. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in areas close to the river around Bourton on the Water. 

The weather forecast is mostly dry for the following couple of days. We expect levels to remain high over the next week. Levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall.

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

This message will be updated Thursday morning, 13/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels remain high on the Ginge Brook. Further flooding of low lying land and roads is not expected today but remains possible and water will remain sitting in fields. 

The weather forecast is mostly dry for the following couple of days. We expect levels in the Brook to remain high over the next few days and to remain responsive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated Thursday morning, 13/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels have risen on the River Thame as a result of  rainfall on Sunday night and Monday. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, especially in the areas around Thame, Stadhampton, and Dorchester. 

The weather forecast is mostly dry for the following couple of days. We expect river levels will start to lower later today. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water. 

This message will be updated Thursday morning, 13/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels continue to be high due to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 13/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are high on the Lower Colne due to recent rainfall. Flooding is possible at locations near the River Colne, Frays, Wraysbury and Poyle Channel, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Longford. River levels will begin to fall slowly, but remain high at the moment.
The forecast is mainly dry until Friday 14th February and no further flooding is expected. 
We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels. 
Be aware of local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 10 am on Thursday 13th February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but steady on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of a period of sustained rain. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 12/02/25. Light rainfall is possible in the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/02/25, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.20m and falling. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.71m and falling slowly.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.
The Parrett Relief Channel is open, and pumping is taking place at both Huish Episcopi and Westover pumping stations. Pumps at these stations are running to clear water from the moors as quickly as possible. Dry conditions are forecast for the next couple of days.
Staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on road closures.
This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 13/02/2025, or as the situation changes

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Further light rainfall is forecast later in the week, but no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the lower River Pang and the Sulham Brook. Further flooding of low lying land and roads is not expected today but remains possible and water will remain sitting in fields. 

The weather forecast is mostly dry for the following couple of days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated Thursday morning, 13/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
Tyne and Wear coast

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
The afternoon high tide has passed and there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
Coastal conditions are expected to improve throughout the evening and no flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message:
This alert has been removed. 
Weather conditions are forecast to improve and this alert is not required for tides on Wednesday.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels continue to remain high in response to recent and rainfall. Levels are expected to recede later this week, however flooding of fields and roads is still possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No significant rainfall is forecast in the next few days.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 19/2/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are still high in response to recent rainfall and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Areas most at risk include: the Iwerne and the Pimperne Brook areas. No significant rainfall is forecast in the next few days.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 19/02/2025.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Bourne, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 13/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wylye and tributaries
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 13/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but flow is still within banks along most of the Upper Kennet and its tributaries. Further flooding of low lying land and roads is not expected today but remains possible and water will remain sitting in fields. 

The weather forecast is mostly dry for the following couple of days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated Thursday morning, 13/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the Winterbourne Stream in Bagnor and the River Lambourn in Newbury. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. 

The weather forecast is mostly dry for the following couple of days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and we might see another small rise in river levels later in the week as the land drains. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated Thursday morning, 13/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon from Salisbury to Ringwood
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon and tributaries
items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible from 8:00 AM on 11/02/2025.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.
Further flooding is possible this morning as river levels are forecast to rise due to recent rainfall.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels .
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 13/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Iwerne
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Iwerne Minster. The groundwater level at the Iwerne Hill Farm borehole has risen to 110.6m, and is beginning to fall. No significant rainfall is forecast in the next few days. 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.


Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 18/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high in response to recent rainfall. Levels are still reactive to further rainfall. Areas at risk include; areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. No significant rainfall is forecast in the next few days. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. 

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 19/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period.  Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 18/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourne Valley.  

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding.  We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter.  Low lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 18/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and slowly rising. In the last week, 19mm of rain has been recorded at Bishops Sutton. During this time, the level at Preston Candover has risen by 13cm. At Old Alresford, the level has risen by 18cm. A small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From today 10/02/2025 until Friday 14/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are forecast. Groundwater levels in the area are expected to begin stabilising in the next few days. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 17/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 19th February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 19th February 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high and continuing to rise slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period. Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 18/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wear estuary
items.message:
High tides this afternoon may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible around the high tide between 4:00pm and 6:00pm on 12/02/2025 as a result of wind blown spray and overtopping.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
After the high tide this afternoon‚ the weather is more settled and no further flooding is expected.
This message will be updated by 7:00 PM on 12/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hursley are high and continue to slowly rise. In the last week, 14mm of rain has been recorded at Otterbourne. During this time, the level at Hursley has risen by 36cm. Cellar flooding and sewerage system impacts are expected to be becoming more widespread throughout the village. From today 10/02/2025 until Friday 14/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are forecast. Groundwater levels are expected to begin stabilising over the next few days. Cellar flooding and sewerage system impacts may become more widespread while groundwater levels continue to rise. Internal ground floor flooding will be possible if further heavy rain affects the area over the coming weeks. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 17/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover remain very high. In the last week, 10mm of rain has been recorded at Andover. During this time, the level at Clanville has risen by 24cm. Cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing in Appleshaw and Hatherden, as well as being possible in Penton Grafton. Impacts to the sewerage systems are occurring in Penton Mewsey and Appleshaw. Groundwater is flooding the main road into Penton Grafton and is emerging into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton, and will begin to flood the road from Biddesden to Appleshaw in the next few days. From today 10/02/2025 until Friday 14/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are forecast. The groundwater level at Clanville is expected to stabilise in the next few days. Cellar flooding in Kimpton and surface water flood risk in Thruxton could occur before the end of February if further heavy rain affects the area. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 17/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high and continue to slowly rise. In the last week, 17mm of rain has been recorded at Overton. During this time, the level at Oakley has risen by 46cm. In Deane, cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing. Groundwater will be affecting the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. From today 10/02/2025 until Friday 14/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are forecast. Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are expected to continue rising slowly for around 2 weeks. It is possible that the access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) will need to be closed before the end of February. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 17/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are continuing to rise slowly at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding.  We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter.  Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 18/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Till
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain are high and are forecast to rise further this week. Areas that could be affected include: Tilshead, Orcheston, Shrewton and Berwick St James. The groundwater level at the Tilshead borehole remains high at 99.45m, and is expected to remain high due to recent rainfall. No significant rainfall is predicted for the next few days.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures over the weekend and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 18/02/2025.

items.description: River Mimram in Hertfordshire
items.message:
Flooding is affecting low lying land and roads close to the River Mimram, due to persistent rainfall in December and January, leading to high groundwater levels.

Flooding is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn.

Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. The forecast is mostly dry for the next 5 days with some light rain showers.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation.

This message will be updated by 5 pm, Thursday 13th February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message: Groundwater levels at Lopcombe Corner are high and have risen by 1.49m in the last week. At West Tytherley, the level has risen by 19cm during this time. In Nether Wallop, cellar flooding may be affecting isolated properties. In Over Wallop, land and gardens may be experiencing minor ponding of water, while the river will be out of bank at Broughton. In Pitton, groundwater levels are close to where we would expect sewerage network impacts. From today 10/02/2025 until Friday 14/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are forecast. Groundwater levels at Lopcombe Corner are expected to stabilise in the next few days and then will begin to fall. At West Tytherley, levels will continue rising for another week. Cellar flooding in Pitton and West Tytherley could occur towards the end of February if further heavy rain affects the area. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 17/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Bourne Valley - The Winterbournes
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Gunner, Winterbourne Dauntsey, Winterbourne Earls and Laverstock . The groundwater level at the Queen Manor Farm and Clarendon boreholes has risen significantly and is expected to remain high due to recent rainfall. No significant rainfall is forecast in the next few days. 

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 18/02/2025, or as the situation changes.
